statement:
$$\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=1$$

$x<\tan x$ for $\displaystyle 0<x<\frac{\pi}{2}$.

First, let $\displaystyle 0<x<\frac{\pi}{2}$. Then $0<\cos x<1$. Note
also that

$$\label{tan}
x<\tan x.$$

Multiplying both of this inequality by $\cos x$ yields

$$\label{xcos}
x\cos x<\sin x.$$

By ,

$$\label{x}
\sin x<x.$$

Combining inequalities (\[xcos\]) and (\[x\]) gives

$$\label{sin}
x\cos x<\sin x<x.$$

Dividing by $x$ yields

$$\label{squeeze}
\cos x<\frac{\sin x}{x}<1.$$

Now let $\displaystyle \frac{-\pi}{2}<x<0$. Then
$\displaystyle 0<-x<\frac{\pi}{2}$. Plugging $-x$ into inequality
(\[squeeze\]) gives

$$\label{squeeze-}
\cos (-x)<\frac{\sin (-x)}{-x}<1.$$

Since $\cos$ is an even function and $\sin$ is an odd function, we have

$$\label{-squeeze}
\cos x<\frac{-\sin x}{-x}<1.$$

Therefore, inequality (\[squeeze\]) holds for all real $x$ with
$\displaystyle 0<|x|<\frac{\pi}{2}$.

Since $\cos$ is continuous,
$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0} \cos x=\cos 0=1$. Thus,

$$\label{limits}
1=\lim_{x \to 0} \cos x \le \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x} \le \lim_{x \to 0} 1=1.$$

By the squeeze theorem, it follows that
$\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=1$.

Note that the above limit is also valid if $x$ is considered as a
complex variable.
